source.7513215a:
# Load Packages
import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import warnings
import logging
import folium
from folium.plugins import MarkerCluster
import plotly
import plotly.graph_objs as go
plotly.offline.init_notebook_mode()

# Cleaning up Messages
logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.CRITICAL)
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

# Loading Data
dat = pd.read_csv("../input/fifa19/data.csv")
country_data = pd.read_csv("../input/country-geo/country_data.csv")


# Listing Teams by Group
teams_A = ['England', 'Bulgaria', 'Kosovo', 'Montenegro', 'Czech Republic']
teams_B = ['Ukraine', 'Luxembourg', 'Portugal', 'Serbia', 'Lithuania']
teams_C = ['Northern Ireland', 'Germany', 'Netherlands', 'Estonia', 'Belarus']
teams_D = ['Republic of Ireland', 'Switzerland', 'Denmark', 'Georgia'] # no gilbralter
teams_E = ['Slovakia', 'Wales', 'Hungary', 'Croatia', 'Azerbaijan']
teams_F = ['Spain', 'Sweden', 'Romania', 'Malta', 'Norway', 'Faroe Islands']
teams_G = ['Poland', 'Israel', 'FYR Macedonia', 'Slovenia', 'Austria', 'Latvia']
teams_H = ['France', 'Turkey', 'Albania', 'Iceland', 'Andorra', 'Moldova']
teams_I = ['Belgium', 'Russia', 'Kazakhstan', 'Cyprus', 'Scotland'] # no san marino
teams_J = ['Italy', 'Greece', 'Bosnia Herzegovina', 'Finland', 'Armenia', 'Liechtenstein']
teams_all = pd.Series(teams_A + teams_B + teams_C + teams_D + teams_E + teams_F + teams_G + teams_H + teams_I + teams_J)

# Subsetting to Countries in Euro 2020 Qualifiers
dat = dat[dat.Nationality.isin(teams_all)]
source.9b565975:
# Creating Country Level Dataset
country = pd.DataFrame(dat.Nationality.value_counts().values, dat.Nationality.value_counts().index).reset_index().rename(index=str, columns={"index": "Country", 0: "Counts"})

# Plotting Number of Players by Country in FIFA Dataset
sns.set(rc={'figure.figsize':(11.7*3.5,8.27*1.3)})
plt.xticks(rotation = 45)
sns.set(style="whitegrid")
ax = sns.barplot(x="Country", y="Counts", data=country)
source.27bce407:
# Fixing names in countries dataset
country_data.loc[ country_data.name.str.contains("Bosnia and Herzegovina") ,"name"] = "Bosnia Herzegovina"
country_data.loc[ country_data.name.str.contains("Macedonia") ,"name"] = "FYR Macedonia"

# Subsetting to those in Euros qualifiers
country_data = country_data[country_data.name.isin(teams_all)]

# Adding those in not in dataset
country_data = country_data.append(pd.DataFrame(np.array([['EG', "England",             52.3555, -1.1743], 
                                                          ['NI', "Northern Ireland",    53.1424, -7.6921], 
                                                          ["RI", "Republic of Ireland", 53.4129, -8.2439],
                                                          ["WL", "Wales",               52.1307, -3.7837],
                                                          ["SL", "Scotland",            56.4907, -4.2026]]),
                                                          columns = ['country', 'name', 'latitude', 'longitude'])).reset_index(drop = True)


# Moving Russia lat long to Moscow to fit on map easier
country_data.loc[country_data.name.str.contains("Russia"), "latitude"] = 55.7558
country_data.loc[country_data.name.str.contains("Russia"), "longitude"] = 37.6173

# Fixing data types
country_data.latitude = pd.to_numeric(country_data.latitude)
country_data.longitude = pd.to_numeric(country_data.longitude)

# Formatting data
locations = country_data[['latitude', 'longitude']]
locationlist = locations.values.tolist()

# Adding color
country_data["color"] = 'blue'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_B), "color"] = 'green'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_C), "color"] = 'purple'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_D), "color"] = 'orange'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_E), "color"] = 'darkred'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_F), "color"] = 'darkblue'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_G), "color"] = 'black'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_H), "color"] = 'lightgray'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_I), "color"] = 'darkgreen'
country_data.loc[country_data.name.isin(teams_J), "color"] = 'red'

# Creating map
country_map = folium.Map(location=[51.1657, 10.4515], zoom_start = 3)
for point in range(0, len(locationlist)):
    folium.Marker(locationlist[point], 
                  popup = country_data['name'][point],
                  icon = folium.Icon(color = country_data.color[point], 
                                     icon='globe', 
                                     prefix = "fa")
                  ).add_to(country_map)
country_map
source.ce92ec28:
# The value column has a lot of problems before it can be converted to numeric
# Fix the pound sign
dat.Value = dat.Value.str[1:] # gets rid of the first char

# Fixes K and M
dat.Value = dat.Value.str.replace("M", "000000") # Replaces millions with value
dat.Value = dat.Value.str.replace("K", "000") # Replaces millions with value

# Fixes decimal issues (only goes to 1 decimal)
for i in [("." + format(x,'2d') + "0").replace(" ", "") for x in range(1, 10)]:
    dat.Value = dat.Value.str.replace(i, "", regex = False)

# Finaly can convert value to numeric
dat.Value = pd.to_numeric(dat.Value)

# Making ability vs value plot
plotly.offline.iplot({
    "data" : [go.Scatter(
        x = dat.Overall,
        y = dat.Value,
        mode = 'markers',
        text = dat['Name']
    )],
    "layout": go.Layout(
        title = "Correlation Between Ability and Value",
        hovermode= 'closest',
        xaxis = dict(title = 'Overall Ability'),
        yaxis = dict(title = 'Value (Euros)'))
})
source.ad36da40:
# Making age vs value plot
plotly.offline.iplot({
    "data" : [go.Scatter(
        x = dat.Age,
        y = np.log(dat.Value+1),
        mode = 'markers',
        text = dat['Name']
    )],
    "layout": go.Layout(
        title = "Correlation Between Age and Value",
        hovermode= 'closest',
        xaxis = dict(title = 'Age (Years)'),
        yaxis = dict(title = 'Value (Log Euros)'))
})

source.726739d1:
# Tranforming Data
dat_A = dat[dat.index.isin(dat_A.level_1)]
dat_A = dat_A.groupby(["Nationality", "Club"]).count().reset_index(level =0).groupby("Nationality").ID.nlargest(5).reset_index()

# Making Plot
g = sns.catplot(x="Club", y="ID", hue ="Nationality", data=dat_A,
                kind="bar", palette="muted")
g.fig.set_size_inches(30,10)
plt.xticks(rotation = 90)

# Clearing Space
del dat_A

source.1297a4fa: ### Geography Here are where the countries in the Euro qualifiers are located.
source.1f47f791:
#### Player Ratings

Scotland seems to have the tightest team distribution, but are still below Russia and Belgium. Likely Russia and Scotland will have to battle it out for 2nd with a very talented Belgium team in their group looking to get back on the podium after a weaker showing in the Nations League than their 3rd place finish in the 2018 World Cup.
source.9ca2fc58:
#### Player Ratings

Wow, that's a really tight band for Portugal with no player below 82 in the top 18, you can also see Renaldo labeled as an outlier up there in the 90+ range. If this is any indication, Serbia and Ukraine could be in a close battle to get that second qualifying spot, while it seems like a long shot that Lithuania or Luxembourg advance despite Luxembourg being in second after two games.
source.98c17f2d: ### Ability Correlations Let's take a look at how FIFA 19 ability correlates to a player's value. As we would expect, right before ability hits 70 the player value ramps up. What might be more interesting, is looking at which of these players is a pretty good value and which ones are rip-offs. It appears Kroos is an excellent pick with a value much below his counterparts but his overall skill level is still at 90. Ramos, Kane, and Courtois are also pretty good deals. There are no clear outliers for those that have low ability but high value. The closest is De Bruyne, whose value is 102 million at 91 skill. Hazard (93 million), De Gea (72 million), Modric (67 million), and Ramos (51 million) all have the same ability at a significantly lower value. Mbappe has a similar issue.
source.0738532a:
#### Club Representation

No surprise that the top Spanish players are playing at the top three clubs in Spain arguably the [strongest league in Europe in recent history](https://iffhs.de/the-strongest-national-league-of-the-world-spains-primera-division-again/). The other countries also had many players playing domestically, although at noticeably weaker clubs.
source.f7b77237:
#### Club Representation

The Russian players seem to be heavily distributed between the three different Moscow teams. It also makes sense that 5 of the top Scottish players play for the top team in the Scottish Premiership, Celtic. Belgian players seem to be at teams in the top 5 of the EPL and Bundasliga.
source.cf169c61:
#### Club Representation

Looks like the best Austrian players are playing in the German Bundasliga and the best Polish players are playing in Italy. Hard to really say too much from this since no more than 2 players of one of these nationalities are playing on the same team.

source.2b1e082c: ### Group I Here are results for Group I as of March 27th, 2019: | Position | Team | Played | Won | Drawn | Lost | GF | GA | GD | Points | Qual | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | Belgium | 2 | 2 | 0 | 0 | 5 | 1 | 4 | 6 | Y | | 2 | Russia | 2 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 5 | 3 | 2 | 3 | Y | | 3 | Kazakhstan | 2 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 3 | 4 | -1 | 3 | N | | 4 | Cyprus | 2 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 5 | 2 | 3 | 3 | N | | 5 | Scotland | 2 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | -1 | 3 | N | | 6 | San Marino | 2 | 0 | 0 | 2 | 0 | 7 | -7 | 0 | N |
source.bb2f9b81: ### Player Position I want to see if different player positions have higher median value and ability. Let's take a look at value first. It appears that left attacking mid has a high median compared to the rest of the positions. Left forward has a high variance in value between the 25th and 75th percentile. *Outliers were omitted from these boxplots*
source.526e2822: ## All Country Visualizations ### Counts Let's take a look at how many players each country has in FIFA 19. Looks like England has a good 450 more players than its closest competitor, Germany. There also seems to be a high concentration of players in the top 5 countries. About 51% of all players are English, German, Spanish, French, or Italian.
source.66c27add: The Euro qualifiers are starting up and what better way to get in the soccer spirit than by looking at the teams in competition from their FIFA stats. I'm going to do a general overview of the data and explore more in depth by group. More information about the 2020 Euro qualifiers can be found [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020_qualifying). *Note: Obviously actual player strength will differ from the stats in a video game and there will be sampling biases (where smaller countries will either have no players in the data or will only have the top few), but they should roughly correlate and it should at least be fun to look at* ### **Data Preparation**
source.3e24a9c4:
#### Player Ratings

By these ratings, this looks to be the most balanced group we've seen so far, and the early results show it. All teams but Azerbaijan have won 1 game. With no team assured a playoff game for failing to make it in the top 2, this group will definitely be one to watch to see who slips in.

source.360bd3e2:
#### Club Representation

Let's take a look at what clubs the top players of each country play for.

Again, we're just taking the top 18 from each country and looking at the top 5 clubs those players compete for. It looks like England has a more concentrated pool in the EPL and Czech Republic between Ekstraklasa and the Fortuna Liga teams. The rest don't seem to have a high concentration in a particular team.

source.f17032ec:
#### Club Representation

The theme continues with Juventus being the most popular club for top Italian players and Lazio, Roma, and Milan each containing 2 top 18 Italian players. Greek players also tend to be at Greek clubs. One neat thing is this is the first time in these groups we have a club (Arsenal) who has team members from three different countries in the same group.
source.2eb54b37:
Now let's take a look at ability. The boxplots follow the ones from above. Left attacking mid still has a high median, and left forward has a high median. Additionally, right forward seems to also have a pretty strong median. 

This and the above boxplot seem to indicate that there is a bit of bias in assigning value and ability to different positions.
source.0bdde1b4:
#### Club Representation

After looking at a few of these I'm able to pick up on a theme. The Welsh players also seem to be concentrated in the EPL like the English and Irish, although the quality of teams seem to be closer to Ireland than England.
source.f91177c4:
#### Player Ratings

There were no players listed as being from Gibraltar in the data so we'll only get to look at 4 of the 5 teams in Group D. If this data is to be believed, Switzerland and Denmark should be a pretty tight race for 1st. Both teams had impressive performances at the 2018 world cups. Switzerland made it out of a group with Brazil before falling to Sweden and Demark drawing France (The year's champion) and only losing to Croatia (the runner up) after penalties. More recently, Switzerland had a dominating 5-2 win over a very talented Belgian team in the last group stage match of the Nations League. Although... the Republic of Ireland is off to a good start by winning their first two games. It should be interesting to see if they can keep up the pace.
source.5e1bb07d:
#### Player Ratings

France is probably going to be the favorite in this group after coming off a world cup championship and containing several young, talented players. This boxplot also illustrates the gap between France's skill level and their competition. Iceland will try to replicate last year's success at the Euros where they made it to the quarterfinals before losing to France. To get there, they'll have to first get by Turkey who is off to a perfect start.
source.eb09c6d1: ### Group B Here are results for Group B as of March 27th, 2019: | Position | Team | Played | Won | Drawn | Lost | GF | GA | GD | Points | Qual | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | Ukraine | 2 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 2 | 1 | 1 | 4 | Y | | 2 | Luxembourg | 2 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 3 | 3 | 0 | 3 | Y | | 3 | Portugal | 2 | 0 | 2 | 0 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 2 | N | | 4 | Serbia | 1 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 1 | N | | 5 | Lithuania | 1 | 0 | 0 | 1 | 1 | 2 | -1 | 0 | N |
source.a6c9f272:
#### Club Representation

Germany seems to have its best players concentrated at Bayern and a good share going to other top European clubs. Netherlands also seem to have most of its top players competing domestically with Ajax and PSV hosting the greatest share of its top 18. Belarus, Estonia, and Northern Ireland seem to have players pretty spread out with no club having more than 2 of their respective players.
source.0d34c919:
#### Club Representation

I have to say I'm a bit surprised to see such high team concentration given the trend in the previous groups. Swiss players are heavily represented in the Bundasliga with 4 at Mönchengladbach and 3 at Dortmund. Ireland, like England, also is heavily represented in the EPL, although at noticeably worse clubs.
source.12f36a3e: # Visualizations by Group ### **Group A** Here are results for Group A as of March 27th, 2019: | Position | Team | Played | Won | Drawn | Lost | GF | GA | GD | Points | Qual | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | England | 2 | 2 | 0 | 0 | 10 | 1 | 9 | 6 | Y | | 2 | Bulgaria | 2 | 0 | 2 | 0 | 2 | 2 | 0 | 2 | Y | | 3 | Kosovo | 1 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 1 | N | | 4 | Montenegro | 2 | 0 | 1 | 1 | 2 | 6 | -4 | 1 | N | | 5 | Czech Republic | 1 | 0 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 5 | -5 | 0 | N |
source.2e154b50:
#### Club Representation

Turkey's players are much more concentrated than other countries. The French players are spread out amongst top clubs in Europe such as Barca, Real Madrid, United, and PSG. Many Albanian players seem to compete in Italian clubs and Iceland at mid table EPL teams.
source.c48e04f6:
#### Player Ratings

It looks like the early games are reflecting the FIFA 19 team distributions with Italy leading, Bosnia Herzegovina, Finland, and Greece grouped in a second tier and Armenia and Liechtenstein with no points. Bosnia and Herzegovina and Finland are assured at least a playoff spot, so Italy and Greece have the most to lose for not making it in the top 2 spots.
source.c12bb965: ### Group C Here are results for Group C as of March 27th, 2019: | Position | Team | Played | Won | Drawn | Lost | GF | GA | GD | Points | Qual | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | 1 | Northern Ireland | 2 | 2 | 0 | 0 | 4 | 1 | 3 | 6 | Y | | 2 | Germany | 1 | 1 | 0 | 0 | 3 | 2 | 1 | 3 | Y | | 3 | Netherlands | 2 | 1 | 0 | 1 | 6 | 3 | 3 | 3 | N | | 4 | Estonia | 1 | 0 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 2 | -2 | 0 | N | | 5 | Belarus | 2 | 0 | 0 | 2 | 1 | 6 | -5 | 0 | N |
source.3f4896ba:
#### Player Ratings
Now let's take a look at the overall score of the players of these 5 countries. 

It looks like we have a wide spread of player abilities with England actually having a worse median player than other countries. This actually intuitively makes sense. It might take a higher rating for players outside of the top 5 nations to enter the data. As far as a country's performance goes, a team is only as good as the 11 players it has on the field and those subbed in. 

A better approach to look at national team strength could be to look at the top 18 players or so. Ideally we would look at the players actually on the roster for each of these countries, but I was too tired to look up all of the teams rosters, and given changes between games and the lack of data on some countries' players, this seemed like a reasonable approximate.
source.794177e1:
Now looking at the top 18 players from each country, this is a lot more like what we would expect with England having players rated above their group. This is the approach I'll take for the other groups as well. Looks like Montenegro has an outlier much higher than the team median due to S. Savić and his 80+ rating. The others are pretty bunched up in comparison.

There's not really enough games played right now to see if the FIFA 19 player data is reflective of the team's performance, but we'll have to look and see how these track over time.
source.5518d4f0:
#### Player Ratings

No surprise to see Germany and Netherlands with such high player ratings as the former won the World Cup in 2014 and the latter is the [most successful team to never win the world cup](http://soccerly.com/article/finnal/netherlands-the-best-team-to-never-win-the-world-cup). It is interesting that Germany has such a rating given it was actually in Pot 2 in the draw due to a poor performance in the [UEFA Nations League](https://www.uefa.com/uefanationsleague/season=2019/teams/team=47/index.html) and [2018 World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup). Though the top German players may have higher performances in the their clubs to make up for recently shaky international play.
source.d08abd80:
#### Player Ratings

Spain is quite higher than the rest of the pack, with not much separating Norway, Romania and Sweden. Sweden topped a group with Germany and Mexico and eventually made it to the quarterfinals. Spain, after getting to the to the top of their group failed to advance past Russia in a penalty shootout. The other three countries will be hoping to make it into the Euros after failing to qualify for the world cup in 2018.
source.86a275de:
#### Player Ratings

This looks like a group without a clear favorite. Poland is off to a good start with 2 wins in 2 games, but Austria and Slovenia, who look similar in player rating distribution, have yet to win in their two games. Austria just suffered a convincing 4-2 defeat to Israel whose 75th percentile is below the weakest Austrian player in the top 18. We'll see if they can move up in the remaining games.
source.868be985:
#### Club Representation

Ukraine seems to have most of its best players playing locally, with 7 players competing at Shakhtar Donetsk and 6 at Dynamo Kyic, both located in Ukraine. By comparison, the other countries in the group seems to have players more spread out. Both Portugal and Serbia seem to have players in fairly talented clubs across Europe, although Portugal's list is a little more prestigious.

source.3474d8ff: Does a player's ability deteriorate as they age in FIFA 19? It looks like we have the distribution we'd expect. Players, when they are young, have lower ratings. Eventually, they hit a peak and then drop down. I was curious to see if FIFA depreciated a player's value as they got older and it looks like they do.
